case_vignette: A 62-year-old African American man presents to establish care and to undergo skin examination, which he reports receiving regularly since his sister was diagnosed with melanoma. Examination reveals 3-mm hyperpigmented horizontal bands across the nailbeds of all fingernails, which he reports have been present since his 20s. He denies experiencing any other nail changes or pain. He takes no medications, and he has no history of skin cancer or suspicious moles. He has no relevant medical history. His family history is significant for his sister's melanoma diagnosis, but he has no other family history of skin cancer. He has a history of smoking, but he quit 20 years ago. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history. He has a history of sunburns, but he has not had a sunburn in the past 10 years. He has a history of working outdoors, but he has not worked outdoors in the past 10 years. He has a history of using sunscreen, but he has not used sunscreen in the past 10 years. He has a history of avoiding peak sun hours, but he has not avoided peak sun hours in the past 10 years. He has a history of using a hat, but he has not used a hat in the past 10 years. He has a history of using sunglasses, but he has not used sunglasses in the past 10 years. He has a history of using lip balm with SPF, but he has not used lip balm with SPF in the past 10 years. He has a history of using a moisturizer, but he has not used a moisturizer in the past 10 years. He has a history of using a skin cancer screening tool, but he has not used a skin cancer screening tool in the past 10 years. He has a history of getting regular skin examinations, but he has not gotten regular skin examinations in the past 10 years. He has a history of being aware of his skin, but he has not been aware of his skin in the past 10 years.
